Levulinic acid (LA) has received significant attention as a platform chemical for synthesizing a broad range of bio-based fuels. In this study, a series of HY zeolite immobilized ionic liquid (HY-IL) catalysts have been explored for catalytic conversion of glucose to LA. The catalysts were prepared by immobilizing 1,4 methyl sulfonic acid imidazolium tetrachloroaluminate ([MSIM][AlCl4]) acidic ionic liquid into HY zeolite with various ionic liquid to zeolite weight ratio (0.4, 0.5, 0.6). The synthesized [MSIM][AlCl4] was characterized using CHNS elemental analysis and 1H and 13C NMR. Meanwhile, HY-ILs and parent HY zeolite catalyst were characterized using XRD, FESEM, N2 physisorption, FTIR, TGA, NH3-TPD and pyridine adsorption to determine the catalyst properties. BET surface area and NH3-TPD revealed the surface area of HY-IL decreased, while the acidity of HY-IL increased after the addition of ionic liquid into HY zeolite. Meanwhile, pyridine adsorption revealed addition of ionic liquid increased Lewis acid sites in HY zeolite compared to Brønsted acid sites. Among the catalysts tested, HY-IL-2 exhibited the highest catalytic performance with 62.2% of LA yield from reaction conducted at 180 °C for 6 h using 0.4 g of catalyst and 0.5 wt% of glucose. Utilization of other biomass derivatives (sucrose, maltose, cellulose) under optimum condition demonstrated that LA yield obtained were in the order of glucose > sucrose > maltose > cellulose while oil palm frond (OPF) and empty fruit bunch (EFB) showed comparable LA yield. This study emphasized the potential of zeolite immobilized ionic liquid as catalyst for biomass conversion to LA under mild process condition. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Levulinic acid Ionic liquid Glucose conversion HY zeolite HY zeolite immobilized ionic liquid 1 Introduction Concerns about fossil fuels consumption is pertinent due to the limited reserves available. The emission of greenhouse gasses from fuels consumption is also worrying since it is related to climate change [1]. Therefore, many researches have been conducted to find an alternative for fossil fuels. Biomass has been identified as one of the alternatives since it is abundant, sustainable and renewable. Biomass has received significant attention because it can produce wide range of fuels and chemicals [2]. Among those chemical products, levulinic acid (LA) offers great potential for various applications to produce variety of organic chemicals such as fuel additives, polymer, solvent, food additives, pharmaceutical agents and other bio based chemical [3]. Among the different types of carbohydrates used for production of LA, glucose is more preferable compared to fructose. Even though glucose is less reactive in dehydration process compared to fructose, glucose has advantages in term of cost and abundantly available compared to fructose [4]. The conversion of glucose to LA involved several steps (Fig. 1 ). Generally, glucose undergoes isomerization process to form fructose, which is then dehydrated to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF). Finally, 5-HMF is rehydrated to form LA and formic acid. Various catalysts such as mineral acid [5], zeolite [6], metal chloride [7], solid superacid, ion exchange resin [8], mesoporous niobium catalyst [9] and acidic ionic liquid [10] have been used for producing LA from glucose, cellulose, and biomass. Homogeneous acid catalytic system is effective, but could lead to equipment corrosion, environmental pollution, and cumbersome separation and recycling [11]. One of the approaches to overcome the problem related to homogeneous catalyst is to develop heterogeneous catalysts. Heterogeneous catalyst has several advantages such as easy separation, low cost and recyclable. Ionic liquids are salt that exists at liquid below 100 °C and can be made from various combination of cation and anion [12]. Ionic liquids offer the advantages of low vapor pressure, non-flammability, good thermal stability and tunable properties [13]. For that reason, ionic liquids have been used in wide range of application such as gas separation [14], metal extraction [15], biodiesel production [16], biomass pretreatment [17] and catalyst for chemical conversion especially for LA production. Among them, Shi et al. [18] reported the use of SO3H functionalized ionic liquids to produce 76.5% of LA yield from cellulose at 180 °C for 20 min. Meanwhile, Kumar et al. [19] efficiently use ionic liquid as catalyst for the dehydration of glucose at temperature of 155 °C for 5 h to obtain 56.3% of LA yield. It was suggested that high acidity of ionic liquid is one of the factors culminating to high glucose conversion and LA yield. Despite the excellent activity of ionic liquids, their application is limited due to high cost, complex separation and ionic liquid viscosity [20]. Therefore, to overcome these problems, the concept of supported ionic liquid catalysts (SILC) has been introduced. Generally, SILC required smaller amount of ionic liquid and as consequences minimized the limitation related to ionic liquid in terms of economy, toxicity and viscosity. SILC have been used as catalyst in various chemical reaction such as gas separation [21], oxidative desulfurization [22], esterification [23] and condensation reaction [24]. There are several reports that use SILC for the production of 5-HMF, intermediate compound that undergoes ring cleavage to form LA and formic acid. Saxena et al. [25] reported the use of ionic liquid encapsulated zeolite catalyst for synthesis of 5-HMF from glucose. On the other hand, Xu et al. [26], has applied ionic liquid supported silica gel for synthesis of 5-HMF from various substrates such as fructose, glucose, xylose and sucrose. In terms of catalytic activity, SILC (IL-SO3HHSO4/SiO2) performed quite similar with its ionic liquid (IL-SO3HHSO4) for fructose dehydration to 5-HMF [26]. Among catalyst support, zeolites such as ZSM-5 and HY zeolite have been used for LA production [27,28]. They demonstrated good potential to be used in glucose dehydration due to the pore structures that exert significant effect on the reaction. In addition, the catalytic performance testing of zeolites revealed that the amount and strength of acid sites, types of acid sites also have significant effect on the LA yield and selectivity [27,29]. At 160 °C and 180 min, 100% glucose conversion and up to 15% levulinic acid yield was obtained from glucose conversion catalyzed by HY zeolite [27,29]. It is envisaged that higher LA production at adequate process condition can be obtained by improving the catalyst properties and reactivity. Several approaches can be conducted such as by immobilizing HY zeolite catalyst with acidic ionic liquid. In this study, HY zeolite immobilized ionic liquid catalysts with different ionic liquid and zeolite weight ratios have been synthesized for dehydration of glucose to LA. Characteristics of HY and HY-ILs have been determined using CHNS, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR), X-ray diffraction (XRD), field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), N2 physisorption, Fourier-transformed infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA), temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) and pyridine adsorption. The impact of physicochemical properties of catalysts and process parameters on dehydration of glucose to LA is also investigated. The parameters studied included effect of temperature, time of reaction, catalyst dosage, and feedstock concentration on glucose conversion and product yields. In addition, several biomass (OPF and EFB) and its derivatives (sucrose, maltose and cellulose) were also used as feedstocks and tested over the best catalyst for LA production. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Potassium sodium tartrate tetrahydrate (KNaC4H4O6·4H2O), sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and microcrystalline cellulose were obtained from Sigma Aldrich. HY zeolite (SiO2/Al2O3=30) was purchased from Zeolyst International. Meanwhile, 1-methylimidazole, chlorosulfonic acid (HSO3Cl), 3,5-dinitrosalicyclic acid, D(+)-glucose monohydrate and aluminum chloride (AlCl3) were purchased from Merck, Germany. Sucrose was acquired from Emd Chemicals, Germany. D(+)-maltose monohydrate was acquired from HmbG Chemicals, Germany. A standard analytical grade of levulinic acid (LA) (98%), obtained from Merck and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) 99% (Sigma Aldrich) were used for the analysis of desired products. Distilled water was used for the preparation of solutions. Oil palm frond (OPF) and empty fruit bunch (EFB) were supplied by Malaysian Palm Oil Board (MPOB), Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. The OPF and EFB samples used in this study were similar with the previous works [29,30]. The approximate composition of OPF is 45.2% cellulose, 20.3% hemicellulose, 11.2% lignin, 12.8% moisture and 10.5% ash content, while EFB has 41.0% cellulose, 13.3% hemicellulose, 25.2% lignin, 10.6% moisture content and 8.0% ash content. 2.2 Preparation of 1,4-methylsulfonic acid imidazolium tetrachloroaluminate ([MSIM][AlCl4]) [MSIM][AlCl4] was synthesized in a two-step process as illustrated in Fig. 2 . HSO3Cl was added dropwise to 1-methylimidazole in CH2Cl2 over a period of 5 min in ice bath. The reaction mixture was then stirred for 2 h, let stand for 5 min, before CH2Cl2 was decanted. The residue was washed with CH2Cl2 and dried under vacuum to give 1,4-methylsulfonic acid imidazolium chloride [MSIM][Cl] as a viscous pale-yellow oil. Then, [MSIM][AlCl4] was prepared by adding equimolar amount of AlCl3 to [MSIM][Cl] over a period of 5 min at 50 °C. The reaction mixture was then stirred for 1 h at 50 °C to give [MSIM][AlCl4] as white powder. 2.3 Preparation of zeolite immobilized ionic liquid HY-IL was synthesized according to the method described in literature [31]. HY zeolite was added to [MSIM][AlCl4] in water with certain weight ratio of ionic liquid to zeolite. The mixture was stirred continuously at 90 °C for 12 h. Finally, the catalyst was dried at 70 °C under vacuum to yield HY-IL. The HY-IL with weight ratios 0.4, 0.5 and 0.6 were denoted as HY-IL-1, HY-IL-2 and HY-IL-3, respectively. 2.4 Catalyst characterization The CHNS elemental analysis of [MSIM][Cl] and [MSIM][AlCl4] ionic liquids were characterized using Elemental Analyzer Vario MICRO Cube. The results of 1H NMR and 13C NMR (Fig. S1) were recorded on NMR Bruker Advance II 400 MHz in DMSO‑d6 solvent. Crystalline structure was determined using Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer system with Cu Kα radiation, and the 2θ scanned in the range of 10° to 80°. The average crystallite size was evaluated using Scherrer equation (Eq. (1)). (1) D = k λ β cos θ where, constant k is (0.98), X-ray wavelength, λ is (1.54178 Å), β is the full line width at half maximum intensity diffraction line in radian and θ is the Bragg's angle. The morphology of the samples was observed by FESEM (HITACHI, SU-8000) with STEM detector. All samples were coated with gold and vacuum dried in argon atmosphere. The surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter of the samples were performed on a sorption analyzer (Thermo Scientific, SURFER). Prior to analysis, the sample was dried under vacuum at 200 °C for 4 h. The surface area of HY-IL and HY zeolite catalysts were measured by using Brunauer, Emmett, & Teller (BET) method while the distribution of mesopores and micropores were estimated by using Barrett, Joyner & Halenda (BJH) and Horvath & Kawazoe methods, respectively. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of catalyst samples were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum by using KBr pellets with a resolution of 4 cm–1 and 10 scans in the 4000–400 cm–1 of IR range. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were conducted using thermal analyzer (Netzsch STA 449 F3 Jupiter) instrument. The catalyst sample was heated from 30 °C to 900 °C under N2 flow (10 °C/min). Acid properties of HY-IL and HY zeolite were determined by temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of ammonia using micrometrics Auto Chem II instrument. The catalyst was dried at 200 °C for 1 h under constant nitrogen flow (20 ml/min) and cooled 60 °C. The sample then saturated with NH3 at 60 °C for 0.5 h. The adsorbed NH3 was removed by helium purging at 60 °C for 0.5 h. The sample was heated to 700 °C at a heating rate of 20 °C/min to desorb the NH3. Acid type of catalysts was determined using FTIR spectroscopy with pyridine as probe molecule. The catalyst was pressed in a hydraulic press to obtain 13 mm diameter of self-supporting disk before placing it in the stainless steel IR cell connected with vacuum-adsorption apparatus. Prior to the adsorption measurements, the catalyst was activated at 400 °C for 1 h. The FTIR spectra were recorded in the 1600–1400 cm–1 wavelength. 2.5 Catalytic testing and product analysis The catalytic conversion of glucose was carried out in a high-pressured batch reactor using certain amount of glucose solution and catalyst. The reaction mixture then preheated to a certain temperature. All the prepared catalysts were screened and the selected catalyst was further studied to see the effect of reaction parameters on glucose conversion and product yield and to determine the optimum condition. The variables involved were the reaction temperature (150‒190 °C), reaction time (3‒7 h), catalyst dosage (0.1‒0.5 g), and feedstock concentration (0.3‒4 wt.%). In a typical experiment for biomass transformation to LA, the condition used was the same as the optimum condition obtained from glucose experiment. After experiment, the reactor was let to cooled at room temperature. The dinitrosalicyclic acid (DNS) method was applied to determine glucose conversion. The DNS reagent was prepared by providing 0.02 g/mL of NaOH solution. Next, 80 mL of NaOH solution was mixed with 1 g of dinitrosalicyclic acid, 30 g of KNaC4H4O6·4H2O and 0.83 g of Na2SO3. 1 mL of product sample was mixed with 4 mL of DNS reagent in a test tube. The resulting mixture was heated in boiling water for 5 min. The glucose concentration was calculated using standard calibration of glucose solution with known concentration using UV–Vis spectrophotometer at 540 nm. The concentration of LA and 5-HMF in product sample was quantified by using high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) equipped with UV detector. The column used was Aminex HPX-87H at 60 °C. The mobile phase used was 5 mM H2SO4 with flow rate 0.6 mL/min. The sample concentration was calculated using standard LA and 5-HMF and calibration curve with known concentrations. The conversion and product yield were calculated according to Eqs. (2) and (3), respectively. (2) Glucose conversion ( % ) = Initial glucose amount ( g ) − final glucose amount ( g ) Initial glucose amount ( g ) × 100 % (3) Product yield ( % ) = Final product amount ( g ) Initial glucose amount ( g ) × 100 % 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Elemental analysis and NMR The elements of [MSIM][Cl] and [MSIM][AlCl4] were identified using CHNS analysis. The result obtained was compared with theoretical value. From the analysis, the value is in accordance with the theoretical one confirming the prepared ionic liquids as follow: CHNS analysis (%): [MSIM][Cl]: Calculated C: 24.19, H: 3.53, N: 14.11, S: 16.12; Theoretical C: 24.26, H: 3.52, N: 14.15, S: 16.17; [MSIM][AlCl4]: Calculated C: 14.48, H: 2.11, N: 8.44, S:9.65; Theoretical C: 14.53, H: 2.10, N: 8.39, S: 9.56. The spectral data NMR for [MSIM][Cl]: 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400MHZ): ppm 3.829 (3H, s), 7.543(1H, m), 7.483(1H, m), 8.86(1H, s), 13.999 (1H,s); 13C NMR (DMSO‑d6, 400MHZ): ppm 35.794,119.939, 123.554, 135.902 Spectral data NMR for [MSIM][AlCl4]: 1H NMR (DMSO‑d6, 400MHZ): ppm 3.832 (3H, s), 7.523 (1H, m), 7.600 (1H, m), 8.848 (1H, s); 13C NMR (DMSO‑d6, 400MHZ): ppm 35.389, 121.596, 123.123, 136.551. 3.1.2 X-ray diffraction The XRD patterns of HY zeolite and HY-IL catalysts, depict in Fig. 3 , exhibit the diffraction lines of HY-ILs and HY zeolite. The line observed for HY-zeolite characterized by intense reflection at 2θ equal to 10.2, 12.0, 16.0, 18.9, 20.6, 24.0 and 27.5. Those lines were quite similar with FAU structure as mentioned from previous work [25]. The XRD pattern of HY-ILs were completely matched with the parent of HY zeolite which indicate that no destruction on the zeolite structure after immobilization of ionic liquid. The results are in accordance with previous study, which reported that the immobilization of [BMIM][Cl] ionic liquid onto HY zeolite did not change the zeolite structure [25]. However, the line intensity of HY-ILs was lower than HY zeolite. This could be attributed to the disordering of the porous structure and variation of the electron density due to immobilizing of the ionic liquid onto zeolite [32]. The average crystallite size was estimated at the highest diffraction line (2θ=15°) using Scherrer equation. The calculated size of HY zeolite, HY-IL-1, HY-IL-2, and HY-IL-3 are 42 nm, 45 nm, 49 nm, and 50 nm, respectively. The crystallite size increased after immobilization of ionic liquid onto HY zeolite could be attributed due to the presence of metal from ionic liquid. The effect of addition metal on HY zeolite in increasing crystallite zeolite has been reported in previous work [33]. 3.1.3 Field Emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) The morphology of HY zeolite and HY-IL-2 catalysts, determined using FESEM, is shown in Fig. 4 . At the magnification of 1000× (Fig. 4a), the FESEM image shows the agglomeration of zeolite particles, while at the magnification of 25,000× (Fig. 4b), the FESEM image shows the HY zeolite in polyhedral shape. The FESEM image of HY-IL-2 (Fig. 4c) shows that ionic liquid is well dispersed on the surface of the zeolite. After magnification of 25,000×, HY-IL-2 exhibits a polyhedral shape, similar to the shape of HY zeolite, which indicates that the addition of ionic liquid onto HY zeolite does not affect the zeolite surface structure. 3.1.4 N2 adsorption-desorption analysis The N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of HY and HY-ILs are shown in Fig. 5 . All catalysts exhibit mesoporosity (Type IV isotherms with hysteresis loop) and the microporosity sign (steep increase in adsorption at low relative pressure). The surface area, pore volume and pore size of HY and HY-ILs are summarized in Table 1 . The surface area revealed that the addition of ionic liquid onto HY zeolite reduced the surface area and pore volumes of the catalyst and increased the average pore diameter. Among the HY-ILs, HY-IL-2 exhibits the lowest surface area and pore volume and the highest average pore diameter, which is 300 m2/g, 0.2649 cm3/g, and 3.52 nm, respectively. The increased average pore diameter for HY-ILs is possibly due to the presence of AlCl3, which could block some of the catalyst pores (micropore). Previously, it is reported that the presence of metal in zeolite could block micropores in the HZSM zeolite; thus, increasing the average pore diameter [34]. However, the pore diameter decreased for HY-IL-3 compared to other HY-ILs, possibly due to the presence of more metal ions which caused a stronger disorder of the zeolite channel [35]. The surface area of HY-IL-3 was slightly higher than HY-IL-2 possibly due to the higher crystallinity of HY-IL-3, as observed in XRD analysis. Similar trend also has been reported elsewhere [36]. 3.1.5 Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy The FTIR analysis was performed in the range of 4000−400 cm–1 to determine the structural properties of HY and HY-ILs. As shown in Fig. 6 , no significant changes in band position between HY and HY-ILs is observed, which indicate the immobilization of ionic liquid did not affect the structure of HY zeolite. Generally, IR spectra of HY-zeolite can be divided into two regions; 1300−400 cm–1 and 4000−3000 cm–1. The region between 1300 and 400 cm–1 represent the framework vibration of lattice cell (Si-O-Si or Al-O-Al) unit [37]. All catalysts exhibit a band at 3400 cm–1 , which is attributed to OH group attached to the HY zeolite structure and physiosorbed water [38]. This band infers to the vibration of Si-OH, Al-OH and H-bonded hydroxyl groups. As for the ionic liquid structure, broad band of quaternary amine salt formation and C=C stretching were observed in the band range of 3400 to 3600 cm–1 and at wavenumbers around 1655 cm–1, respectively [39]. Besides, the C=N bond from imidazole ring cation and Al-Cl bond from AlCl4 anion can be detected at 1560 cm–1 [40] and 545 cm–1 [41], respectively. However, no indication of cation or anion from ionic liquid was observed from the spectra for all HY-IL catalysts. The undetected ionic liquid spectra could be due to overlapping with stronger HY zeolite band. The significant change can be observed from the increment of the band intensities of the spectra between 1500 and 400 cm–1. High band intensity was presented by HY-IL-2 sample. The overlapping of S=O and S-O of IL with Si-O-Si of HY zeolite were occurs at wavenumber around 1250–1000 cm–1. According to Khazaei et al. [42], Si-O-Si bonding could be detected at 1083 cm–1. The S=O and S-O bonding of ionic liquid were detected around 1155–1208 cm–1 and 1050 cm–1, respectively [42,43]. Besides, the increasing of band intensity of the spectra between 600 and 400 cm–1 was due to the existence of Al bonding from the ionic liquid and HY zeolite. 3.1.6 Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) The TGA of HY and HY-ILs are shown in Fig. 7 . Variation of mass of samples heated at rate 10 ºC/min from room temperature 30 ºC to 900 ºC. For HY zeolite, the mass losses occurred at one stage whereas for HY-IL, the mass losses were detected at three stages. The temperature range 30−150 ºC for HY zeolite and HY-IL indicated loss of moisture from the catalysts. For temperature above 150 ºC, the mass losses were attributed to the ionic liquid attached on HY-zeolite. The mass losses of HY-IL structure, observed at temperature range of 200−500 ºC, was mainly due to the decomposition of ionic liquid structure. As reported before, the ionic liquid tend to decompose in the range temperature of 200−500 ºC [44,45]. For temperature above 550 ºC, the mass loss is from decomposition of sulfonic acid groups from the ionic liquid. The result is in parallel with previous studies which reported the decomposition of sulfonic groups at temperature above 500 ºC [46]. 3.1.7 Catalyst acidity TPD-NH3 is carried out to investigate the acidic properties of the catalysts. Generally, the NH3 peak can be classified as weak, moderate and strong acid sites based on desorption temperature. The desorption temperature depends on strength of interaction between NH3 and the surface acid sites and amount of desorbed species [27,47]. The NH3-TPD profile and acidity strength of HY zeolite and HY-ILs are shown in Fig. 8 (a). The acid sites of HY zeolite concur with previous studies where two desorption peaks of ammonia are detected at low and moderate temperature [48]. The strength of the acid site increased with the addition of ionic liquid onto HY zeolite. The amount of acid sites is quantified in Table 2 . The total acidity of the HY-IL catalysts is higher compared to the total acidity of HY zeolite. HY-IL-2 catalyst registers the highest total acidity of 9.3 mmol/g at three different desorption peaks: weak (4.25 mmol/g), moderate (3.86 mmol/g) and strong (1.18 mmol/g) acid strength. Meanwhile, HY-IL-3 gives lower total acidity (8.38 mmol/g) compared to HY-IL-2 catalyst. The results indicate that the acidity of HY-IL catalysts is contributed by the acidity of ionic liquid. However, the total acidity of HY-IL catalysts is not directly correlated to the amount of ionic liquid loading, which suggested that it is attributed by the interaction between HY zeolite and ionic liquid in the catalysts. Similarly, the acid sites density is in the following order; HY-IL-2 > HY-IL-3 > HY-IL-1. Infrared spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine is used to identify Brønsted and Lewis acid sites of the catalysts as shown in Fig. 8(b). The Brønsted and Lewis acid sites can be observed at band 1540 cm–1 and 1450 cm–1, respectively. In addition, the band of 1490 cm–1 shows both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [49]. The intensity of the band assigned to Brønsted acid sites decreases in following order: HY-IL-3, HY-IL-2, HY-IL-1, HY zeolite. Generally, the presence of Brønsted acid site from the HY zeolite is due to bonding of hydroxyl group and Al-framework [48]. Meanwhile, Brønsted acid sites in HY-ILs could be due to the presence of sulfonic acid group in ionic liquid. Ion exchange may occur between sulfonic acid group in ionic liquid and H + from HY zeolite as reported in previous work [32]. For Lewis acid sites in zeolite, it can be detected with defects, amorphous part and extra framework of Al species. From the spectra, it can be observed that HY-IL catalysts confer higher Lewis acid sites compared to Brønsted acid sites. The Brønsted to Lewis acid ratio decrease with addition of ionic liquid to HY zeolite (as shown in Table 2). Tetrachloroaluminate anion in ionic liquid contributes to the increase of Lewis acid in HY-IL and decrease the ratio of Brønsted to Lewis acid ratio. 3.2 Catalytic performance The catalytic performances of HY-IL catalysts were evaluated based on production of LA from glucose. Catalyst screening was conducted by comparing catalytic activity of HY-IL-1, HY-IL-2, and HY-IL-3. The product distributions of LA and 5-HMF for the three catalysts samples are presented in Fig. 9 (a). The catalytic activity was performed at temperature 180 °C for 4 h of reaction time. In this study, the main product from glucose reaction using HY-IL catalyst is LA. High LA yield and low 5-HMF yield were observed during the reaction. The reason for low 5-HMF yield is due to decomposition of 5-HMF to other products at the reaction condition. Theoretically, LA and formic acid are simultaneously produced from 5-HMF rehydration in an equal molar ratio [47,50]. However, in this study, formic acid yield is not reported due to the low amount observed throughout this study. This condition happened possibly due to the decomposition of formic acid at the reaction condition. From literatures, different trends were anticipated on formic acid at high reaction temperature. It is reported that there is tendency of formic acid decomposition to CO2, H2, CO, and H2O in heat and acidic mediums [27,51]. Besides, there are studies on reduction of formic acid due to its used as internal hydrogen source for hydrogenation of LA to gamma valerolactone under reducing condition [52]. In contrast, no occurrence of formic acid decomposition was reported on glucose conversion at 155 °C, where at 36% of LA yield, 24% of formic acid yield was observed [19]. Besides, as LA yield reached 64% from glucose at 180 °C, the formic acid yield rose up to 13% and decreased slightly after 1.5 h [51]. Based on these trends, it is suggested that there are various factors that could contributed to the fate of formic acid at the reaction condition. Further investigations are required to examine the factors and trends of formic acid produced. Among HY-IL catalysts tested for conversion of glucose to LA, HY-IL-2 depicts the highest glucose conversion and LA yield. The distribution of product from glucose dehydration is related to the physicochemical properties of the catalysts such as acidity and porosity of the catalysts. From previous study, strong acid sites play important role in the conversion of glucose to LA [53]. High acid site concentration is required for the reaction pathway of glucose to LA. Generally, glucose isomerizes to fructose then undergoes dehydration process to produce 5-HMF followed by rehydration of 5-HMF to LA and formic acid. As shown in Fig. 9(b), the amount of acid sites per unit surface area of catalysts is parallel with the LA yield. Therefore, it can be deduced that the highest LA yield is attributed to HY-IL-2 containing the highest acid sites compared to other HY-ILs. In addition, the turnover frequency (TOF) for each catalyst is calculated. The calculation is based on the total acidity of catalyst determined by NH3-TPD. From the calculation, the TOF for HY, HY-IL-1, HY-IL-2 and HY-IL-3 are 0.0403, 0.0882, 0.124 and 0.111 h–1, respectively. The TOF increased after the addition of IL onto HY zeolite. As indicated from the acid sites and TOF calculation, the amount of acid sites greatly influenced the LA production from glucose. Other than the strength of acidity, type of acidity also influenced the production of LA from glucose. This phenomenon can be seen at the effect of Brønsted to Lewis acid sites ratio on LA yield and glucose conversion as shown in Fig. 9(c) and (d). At lower Lewis acid sites for HY zeolite, the glucose conversion is low, which is supported by the fact that Lewis acid sites is required for isomerization of glucose [54,55]. In this study, all HY-ILs registered higher Lewis acid sites and higher LA yield compared to HY zeolite (high Bronsted acid sites) after immobilization of ionic liquid. This is supported by the fact that both Bronsted and Lewis acid sites are required for dehydration reaction [54,56]. Meanwhile, Bronsted acid sites is essential for rehydration of 5-HMF to LA [54,56]. This effect can be seen for lower LA yield for HY-IL-3 with the lowest Bronsted acid sites. However, the increase in Lewis acid sites can negatively impact the LA production by catalyzing the decomposition of glucose to form humins [49]. It was observed that the LA production was lower for HY-IL-3 compared to the other two HY-IL catalysts tested, since HY-IL-3 possessed higher Lewis acid sites. The high activity demonstrated by HY-IL-2 is due to its high acidity comprised of both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites as well as the synergistic effect of acidity and catalyst porosity. For zeolite catalytic system, porosity of zeolite plays important role in the catalytic activity. Previous study has reported that the pore size could influence the dehydration rate of glucose. In this study, the size of micropore among the HY-IL catalysts is smaller compare to the glucose molecule (0.90 nm). Therefore, the glucose molecule did not enter into the micropores of HY-ILs. Instead, the dehydration of glucose occurred outside the HY-IL micropore. Although LA was formed in the micropores as reported previously [55], the mesopores could also influence the glucose dehydration [47]. Among the HY-ILs, HY-IL-2 and HY-IL-3 were more selective due to smaller mesopore volume [27,57]. Low yield of LA in HY-IL-1 could be due to large mesopore volume in the catalyst. It was reported that too large mesoporous volume in aqueous solution could increase local protonic acid thus, promoted some side reactions such as fragmentation and polymerization reaction [27]. In addition, possible leaching of small amount of ionic liquid could occur in solution under reaction condition and subsequently involve in the reaction. As comparison, HY zeolite, HY-ILs and [MSIM][AlCl4] ionic liquid catalysts were employed for LA production from glucose at 180 °C for 4 h as shown in Fig. 9(d). From the testing, it can be observed that glucose conversion, LA yield and LA selectivity obtained using HY and IL parent catalysts were lower compared to HY-IL catalysts. Based on this result, immobilizing [MSIM][AlCl4] ionic liquid onto HY zeolite displayed high catalytic activity compared to the parent catalysts. Both ionic liquid and HY catalysts play important role in high conversion of glucose and producing high LA yield and selectivity. Ionic liquid provided sufficient acidity to the HY zeolite for the reaction pathway of glucose to LA. HY zeolite also contributed to LA production through porosity in the whole process [58]. Since HY-IL-2 gave the highest LA yield, HY-IL-2 has been selected for studying the effect of reaction parameters. Four different parameters were investigated including reaction temperature, reaction time, catalyst dosage and feedstock concentration. Initially, the experiments were carried out to study the effect of temperature on glucose conversion and product distribution from 150 °C to 190 °C for 4 h as shown in Fig. 10 (a). It can be observed that the conversion of glucose increased as the temperature increased. The highest glucose conversion was registered at temperature of 190 °C which is more than 90%. As for the product yield, highest 5-HMF yield was detected at temperature of 150 °C. As temperature increased, the 5-HMF yield decreased until at temperature of 190 °C. The decreased of 5-HMF yield with increasing temperature is due to decomposition of 5-HMF. There are three possible reactions of 5-HMF decomposition which are (1) 5-HMF rehydrated to LA and formic acid, (2) aldol condensation of 5-HMF into soluble polymer and (3) cross polymerization of 5-HMF and glucose to form humin [49]. In contrast, LA yield increased with increasing temperature from 150 to 180 °C. The highest LA yield was obsrved at 180 °C with 53%. Above 190 °C, it was observed that the LA yield decreased. At 180 °C, no 5-HMF yield was observed which indicated that the 5-HMF fully converted to LA. Meanwhile, less LA could be due to the side reaction and byproduct formation. The dark brown color of liquid product observed during the experiment could be related to formation of insoluble byproduct humin [59]. Thus, the result shows that optimal temperature for conversion of glucose to LA is 180 °C The effect of reaction time for glucose conversion and product distribution can be seen in Fig. 10(b). The reaction time tested for glucose dehydration is from 3 to 7 h. From the result, longer reaction time for dehydration of glucose, higher conversion of glucose and higher LA yield can be observed. Low 5-HMF yield can be observed for all the reaction time from 3 to 7 h. The highest LA can be achieved is at 6 h of reaction time. Prolonging reaction time to 7 h resulted in lower LA yield. The decrease of LA yield could be due to undesired side reaction at prolonged reaction time [49]. It is obvious the reaction time has significant influenced on LA yield. From the analysis, 6 h of reaction time was selected for the next parameter study. Catalyst dosage is an important parameter that determines the 5-HMF and LA yield. The effect of HY-IL-2 dosage on the glucose conversion and product distribution can be seen in Fig. 10(c). The amount of catalyst was varied from 0.1 g to 0.5 g at 180 °C for 6 h while maintaining the amount of glucose (0.4 g). The glucose conversion and LA yield increased as the amount of HY-IL-2 increased from 0.1 g to 0.4 g. The highest LA yield was obtained when the amount of HY-IL-2 is 0.4 g. The higher catalyst dosage indicated higher catalyst acid sites in the dehydration reaction, those increased the LA yield. However, at catalyst dosage of 0.5 g, the LA yield lowered. This could be due to high catalyst dosage results high viscous liquid mixture, therefore reducing the effect of mixing during reaction. The effect of high viscosity of liquid mixture on glucose conversion and product yield has been discussed previously [60,61]. From the analysis, catalyst loading 0.4 g was selected for the next study. Feedstock concentration is important for economic benefit and friendly environment. The effect of feedstock concentration on glucose conversion and product distribution is shown in Fig. 10(d). The feedstock concentration was varied from 0.3 to 4 wt.% while maintaining the catalyst dosage. It can be observed that the glucose conversion and LA yield lowered with the increase of feedstock concentration. The glucose conversion and LA yield were lowered due to insufficient catalyst acid site with respect to high concentration of feedstock at the experimental condition [62]. The highest yield of LA could be obtained at glucose concentration of 0.5 wt.% which is at 62.2%. 3.3 Catalyst reusability The reusability of HY-IL-2 catalyst is investigated in this study and the results are presented in Table S1. The performance of HY-IL-2 reusability was conducted for four runs and performed at 180 °C for 6 h using 0.4 g HY-IL-2. It was clear that, LA yield reduced for each cycle from 62.2 (first run) to 25.1% (fourth run). The decrease of the catalytic activity could be due to the loss of the catalyst during the catalyst recovery process and the deposition of insoluble solid (humins) on the catalyst surface. For investigating the possibility of Al leaching from HY-IL-2 into the solution, experimental samples conducted using HY-IL-2 catalyst at 180 °C for 6 h were subjected to ICP-OES. The amount of Al was found to be less than 2% of the starting Al. This infers that the glucose dehydration occurred mainly due to catalytic activity of HY-IL-2 catalyst; including the Al present on the catalyst surface, rather than the trace amount of leached Al. 3.4 Proposed reaction mechanism The mechanism of glucose conversion to LA over HY immobilized ionic liquid is depicted in Fig. 11 . Initially, glucose undergoes isomerization reaction to fructose through intramolecular hydride shift by the presence of AlCl3 from ionic liquid [63,64]. Then, unreacted glucose and fructose opened to linear chain in the form of 1,2 enediol molecule. The linear molecules 1,2 enediol entered the pores and dehydrated to 5-HMF. It was reported previously that H +released through ion exchange between [BMIM]+ from ionic liquid and Brønsted acid sites from zeolite could favor dehydration of fructose to 5-HMF [65]. As described previously, the types of catalyst acidity influence the overall pathway of glucose conversion to LA [54–56]. Isomerization of glucose to fructose is catalyzed by Lewis acid sites, and both Bronsted and Lewis acid sites are required for dehydration to 5-HMF, whereas Brønsted acid sites is essential for 5-HMF rehydration to LA. Moreover, Lewis acid sites are also able to catalyze the decomposition of glucose to form humins. Catalyst porosity plays important role in conversion of fructose to 5-HMF. It was reported that catalyst with larger pore diameter produce higher 5-HMF compared to catalyst with smaller diameter [66]. Inside the pore, due to spatial limitation, 5-HMF cannot diffuse out of the pore catalyst [67]. 5-HMF is not stable in water and thus dehydrated to linear molecule such as LA and formic acid in acidic medium. The porosity of catalyst affected LA yield. The catalyst with too large mesoporous diameter could reduce LA yield as this condition could promote parallel reaction of glucose dehydration such as fragmentation and polymerization [47,55]. Therefore it can be concluded that catalytic reaction of glucose to LA was influenced by acid sites; both Bronsted and Lewis acids, porous structure and interaction between ionic liquid and zeolite. 3.5 Production of LA from carbohydrate and biomass Product distribution namely LA and 5-HMF from various carbohydrates and biomass feedstocks using HY-IL-2 as catalyst are exhibited in Fig. 12 . 5-HMF yield obtained from all the sample was low due to prolonged reaction time and the presence of water in dehydration system. LA yield from sucrose was comparable to glucose. This infers that HY-IL-2 can efficiently breakdown 1,2-glycosidic bond in sucrose to produce fructose and glucose, dehydrate to 5-HMF and subsequently converted to LA. Since HY-IL-2 efficiently dehydrates glucose to LA and fructose is more reactive than glucose, it can be explained why LA yield from sucrose is comparable to glucose. However, LA yield from maltose was lowered compared to sucrose. This could be due to 1,4-glycosidic bond in maltose is more stable and more difficult to hydrolyze than 1,2-glycosidic bond in sucrose as reported before [68]. We also tested cellulose, one of the polysaccharides for LA production. It can be observed that LA yield from cellulose was lower compared to disaccharide. This could be due to lack of cellulose solubility in aqueous medium and low accessibility of the (1–4) link bond in cellulose to the hydrogen ions localize in the solid acid catalyst [69]. Raw biomass (OPF and EFB) were tested and the LA yields compared with the other feedstocks. As expected, LA yield from raw biomass was lower compared to other carbohydrate feedstocks due to its more complex structure. Protein and ash that are present in biomass could affect conversion of cellulose to LA [70]. In this study, LA yield from both biomass is comparable eventhough cellulose content from OPF (45.2%) is higher than EFB (41.0%). This could be due to the decomposition of cellulose in OPF to other compounds such as formic acid, furan derivative, humin and lactic acid [30]. Fig. 13 depicts the mass balance of one pot reaction of LA production from the biomass waste, EFB with basis of 100 g in the presence of HY-IL-2 catalyst at 180 at 6 h. Theoretically, for conversion of biomass, LA can be produced either by route C6 (cellulose) or C5 (hemicellulose). For LA formation through the hemicellulose, hydrogen molecule was required to convert furfural to furfuryl alcohol [71]. Therefore, in this study, it was assumed that LA was formed through the cellulose route. After the hydrolysis reaction, it was observed that the liquid product appeared as dark brown which could be attributed to humin. It was reported during the formation of LA from biomass, humin was also produced as side-product, which was formed from intermediate product such as 5-HMF and glucose [72]. It was reported that lignin, one of the biomass components, was inert during the conversion, while cellulose and hemicellulose converted to other products during the hydrolysis reaction when catalyzed by ionic liquid [72]. After the hydrolysis reaction, the filtration step was employed to separate the solid residue which contained lignin, unreacted EFB and liquid product. The liquid product consisted of 13.2 g LA, 7.9 g formic acid, 0.4 g 5-HMF and other products. LA was separated from the other liquid products using chromatography. Chromatography was chosen as the separation technique due to its effectiveness compared to other techniques. 4 Conclusions HY immobilized ionic liquid with various ionic liquid to zeolite weight ratios have been successfully prepared and employed for the catalytic conversion of glucose to LA. The catalyst characterizations using XRD, FESEM and FTIR indicate that no structure change occurs after immobilization of ionic liquid to HY-zeolite. BET surface area and NH3-TPD reveal that the addition of ionic liquid reduces the surface area and increases the acidity of HY zeolite. Lewis acid sites also increases after addition of ionic liquid onto HY zeolite. Immobilization of ionic liquid onto HY zeolite improves the catalytic activity towards the production of LA from glucose in which HY-IL-2 produces the highest LA yield. The catalytic performance of the HY-ILs is influenced by amount of acid sites, reactive sites and porosity. The reaction parameters such as temperature, time of reaction, catalyst dosage, and feedstock concentration render significant effect on LA yield from glucose. The best catalytic activity is performed by HY-IL-2 at temperature of 180 °C in 6 h of reaction time corresponding to 62.2% LA yield. Under optimum condition, LA yield from sucrose is comparable to glucose and higher than maltose and cellulose. Meanwhile, OPF and EFB biomass confer comparable LA yield. This work demonstrates the potential of HY-IL as a catalyst for biomass transformation to platform chemicals under mild condition. coredata.dc:description: Levulinic acid (LA) has received significant attention as a platform chemical for synthesizing a broad range of bio-based fuels. In this study, a series of HY zeolite immobilized ionic liquid (HY-IL) catalysts have been explored for catalytic conversion of glucose to LA. The catalysts were prepared by immobilizing 1,4 methyl sulfonic acid imidazolium tetrachloroaluminate ([MSIM][AlCl4]) acidic ionic liquid into HY zeolite with various ionic liquid to zeolite weight ratio (0.4, 0.5, 0.6). The synthesized [MSIM][AlCl4] was characterized using CHNS elemental analysis and 1H and 13C NMR. Meanwhile, HY-ILs and parent HY zeolite catalyst were characterized using XRD, FESEM, N2 physisorption, FTIR, TGA, NH3-TPD and pyridine adsorption to determine the catalyst properties. BET surface area and NH3-TPD revealed the surface area of HY-IL decreased, while the acidity of HY-IL increased after the addition of ionic liquid into HY zeolite. Meanwhile, pyridine adsorption revealed addition of ionic liquid increased Lewis acid sites in HY zeolite compared to Brønsted acid sites. Among the catalysts tested, HY-IL-2 exhibited the highest catalytic performance with 62.2% of LA yield from reaction conducted at 180 °C for 6 h using 0.4 g of catalyst and 0.5 wt% of glucose. Utilization of other biomass derivatives (sucrose, maltose, cellulose) under optimum condition demonstrated that LA yield obtained were in the order of glucose > sucrose > maltose > cellulose while oil palm frond (OPF) and empty fruit bunch (EFB) showed comparable LA yield. This study emphasized the potential of zeolite immobilized ionic liquid as catalyst for biomass conversion to LA under mild process condition.
coredata.dc:title: Zeolite immobilized ionic liquid as an effective catalyst for conversion of biomass derivatives to levulinic acid
